awd_titl_txt: A Consortium Approach to CS for All
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been a strong push to expand the opportunities for students to experience Computer Science (CS) instruction in schools across the nation. To support the work at the federal, state, local levels and engage others in the effort, there is a need for coordination across these sectors. The current complex landscape does not have a central organization or connection point, thereby leaving many local education agencies (LEAs) unsure of how to proceed. Using a collective impact model, the New York City Foundation for Computer Science Education will lead an effort to engage leaders in the field to provide local actors access to resources as part of the larger federal Computer Science for All Initiative (CS for All) access to resources for states and local education agencies to support implementation of computer science education across the nation. 

The consortium will work with a broad range of stakeholders involved in policy making, funding, and implementing computer science education across the nation in order to: effectively coordinate bodies participating in the execution of CS for All; create and launch a steering committee to guide CS for All; develop and build consensus around a common vision and objectives for CS for All in collaboration with a national steering committee; design and execute a knowledge sharing strategy for all who are participating in CS For All: states, districts, schools, teachers and students; and purposefully champion issues of diversity, inclusion and access facing CS Education.

inst.inst_name: The New York City Foundation for Computer Science Education

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The New York City Foundation for Computer Science Education

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
Computer Science for All is a bold initiative to empower all US students from kindergarten through high school to learn computer science and be equipped with the computational thinking skills they need to be creators in the digital economy and active citizens in our technology-driven world. Our economy is rapidly shifting, and educators, policy makers, families, and business leaders are increasingly recognizing that computer science (CS) is a “new basic” skill necessary for economic opportunity and social mobility.

At a convening in early 2016, the national K-12 CS education community including representatives from government, universities, researchers, local practitioners, and national nonprofits (Code.org, CSTA, NCWIT, ACM, and the College Board) declared a need for a hub organization to coordinate and support efforts across the country. Later that year, CSNYC responded by launching the CSforALL Consortium with support from the National Science Foundation to serve as a convener of all K-12 CS education stakeholders, provide a “front door” for newcomers, and support the rapid expansion of the movement across the country.

The Consortium was established with the following goals:

(1) Coordinate stakeholders participating in the execution of CSforALL

 Today, the Consortium represents a membership of more than 400 individuals and organizations including content providers, education associations, researchers, and funders of computer science education to connect and share their work and help school districts and other organizations offer CS to all students. Together with our membership, we set a collective agenda to help schools and districts provide all students with rigorous K-12 computer science education. The Consortium connects directly with this community through a number of channels including the CSforALL website (www.csforall.org) where members can be listed in a searchable index; by offering regular “office hours” for stakeholders interested in receiving guidance, feedback, or connections to other organizations or initiatives; and monthly “community calls” that enable members to share about their work.

 

(2) Form a steering committee to guide CSforALL

 During the grant period, the Consortium was advised by a steering committee comprising representatives from the Association of Computing Machinery (ACM), the College Board, the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA), and the National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT).

 

(3) Develop a knowledge sharing strategy for participants in local efforts connected to CSforALL

The Consortium engages in communications, resource building, and direct consultation and support for community members in line with our mission and strategy. Each month, The Consortium holds a monthly “community call” as a virtual meeting in which members can share their work, highlight best practices and resources, and connect to discuss topics of common concern in CS education.

Community Calls by Date

(most recent first)

Registered Attendees

May 2018 Community Call: Featuring the Constellation Center for Equity in Computing at Georgia Tech

57

April 2018 Community Call: Featuring Everyone Can Code from Apple

100

March 2018 Community Call: Celebrating Women’s HIstory Month, Featuring NCWIT

59

November 2017 Community Call: CSforALL Summit Recap and Next Steps

65

October 2017 Community Call: Accessibility, Featuring Access CSforALL

58

September 2017 Community Call: School District Case Study-Park City School District + Boot-Up PD

47

August 2017 Community Call: Universal Design for Learning, Ensuring the Al in CSforALL

92

July 2017 Community Call: Case Study - CSforALL NYC

69

June 2017 Community Call: CSforALL Case Study: CS4NH, Expanding K12 CS Education in New Hampshire!

48

May 2017 Community Call: Discover how Rhode Island (CS4RI) brought CS into their schools!

39

April 2017 Community Call: CS Education Research

117

March 2017 Community Call: Teacher Support and Professional Development

75

November 2016 Community Call: Arkansas State/Local Implementation of CSforALL

127

October 2016 Community Call: Intro to CSforALL Consortium

144

 

(4) Build consensus around a common vision and objectives for CSforALL

CSforALL embodies a vision in which our educational systems provide equitable and accessible K-12 computer science education so that all students will be informed citizens who critically engage in a modern, technology-driven world; develop as learners, users, and creators of computational knowledge and artifacts; better understand the role of computing in the world around them; and learn, perform, and express themselves with computing across other subjects and interests.

 

(5) Champion issues of diversity, inclusion, and access facing CS education

The Consortium team and our members address diversity, inclusion, and expanding access to all students through our programs. Many community calls address these topics, as well, including the May 2018 call featuring the Constellation Center for Equity in Computing at Georgia Tech, which focuses on serving students of color, Apple’s Everyone Can Code initiative, which leverages accessibility features embedded in their platform. The August 2017 community call focused on Universal Design for Learning and explored real-life examples, common barriers, and strategies educators can use to ensure computer science education is the needs of ALL students, including those who struggle academically or students with disabilities.
